Abstract

Multi-Source Domain Adaptation (MSDA) is a challenging scenario where multiple related and heterogeneous source datasets must be adapted to an unlabeled target dataset. Conventional MSDA methods often overlook that data holders may have privacy concerns, hindering direct data sharing. In response, decentralized MSDA has emerged as a promising strategy to achieve adaptation without centralizing clientsâ€™ data. Our work proposes a novel approach, Decentralized Dataset Dictionary Learning, to address this challenge. Our method leverages Wasserstein barycenters to model the distributional shift across multiple clients, enabling effective adaptation while preserving data privacy. Specifically, our algorithm expresses each clientâ€™s underlying distribution as a Wasserstein barycenter of public atoms, weighted by private barycentric coordinates. Our approach ensures that the barycentric coordinates remain undisclosed throughout the adaptation process. Extensive experimentation across five visual domain adaptation benchmarks demonstrates the superiority of our strategy over existing decentralized MSDA techniques. Moreover, our method exhibits enhanced robustness to client parallelism while maintaining relative resilience compared to conventional decentralized MSDA methodologies.

Keywordsâ€‚Federated Learning Â â‹…â‹…\cdot Domain Adaptation Â â‹…â‹…\cdot Dataset Dictionary Learning Â â‹…â‹…\cdot Optimal Transport

1 Introduction

Supervised machine learning models are trained with large amounts of labeled data. However, these models are subject to performance degradation, if the data used for training does not exactly resembles those used for test. This issue is known in the literature as dataset, or distributional shiftÂ [1]. For instance, in computer vision, factors such as illumination, pose and image quality can induce changes in the data underlying distributionÂ [2, 3]. In this context Multi-Source DA (MSDA)Â [4, 5] emerged as a strategy to adapt multiple, heterogeneous, labeled source datasets towards an unlabeled target dataset.

Nonetheless, standard methods in MSDA overlook that datasets may be divided over multiple clients, rather than centralized on a server. Due to privacy concerns, these clients may not want to centralize their data. Motivated by this challenge, decentralized MSDA is a possible solution to this problemÂ [6, 7, 8]. In parallel to this strategy, distributional shift has been considered by the federated learning literatureÂ [9, 10]. However, concerning domain adaptation, non-i.i.d. federated learning strategies are limited since they do not exploit unlabeled target domain data.

Existing methods in decentralized MSDA mainly follow 2 strategies. First, one may align the multiple existing distributions in a latent space, by learning invariant featuresÂ [6]. Second, on top of aligning distributions, one may perform pseudo-labeling of the target domain through classifiers learned on the source domainsÂ [7, 8]. While invariant representation learning is an important component in domain adaptation, it poses a trade-off between classification performance and domain invarianceÂ [11], which may limit domain adaptation performance. We thus take a different route by modeling the shift between domains in a Wasserstein space.

In parallel, Optimal Transport (OT) is a mathematical theory concerned with the displacement of mass at least effort. This theory previously contributed to the diverse landscape of Domain Adaptation (DA), both in single-sourceÂ [12, 13] and multi-sourceÂ [14, 15, 16] settings. OT is especially advantageous, as it is sensitive to the geometry of the data ambient spaceÂ [17]. In addition, it allows for the definition of averages of probability distributions through Wasserstein barycentersÂ [18], which has been previously used for DAÂ [14, 15, 5]. Overall, OT presents a principled framework for developing DA algorithmsÂ [19].

Given the aforementioned limitations of invariant representation learning, we offer a novel, OT-based method that learns how to express clientsâ€™ underlying probability distribution as a Wasserstein barycenter of learned atoms, weighted by barycentric coordinates. As such, our method effectively keeps clientsâ€™ distributions private, because their barycentric coordinates do not need to be communicated. To the best of our knowledge, ours is the first OT-inspired decentralized DA algorithm, which does not align clientsâ€™ distributions. Our contributions are threefold,

  1. 1.

    We propose a novel strategy, called Federated Dataset Dictionary Learning (FedDaDiL), for performing decentralized dictionary learning over empirical distributions. This strategy has the advantage of keeping the variables that allow to reconstruct clientsâ€™ data distributions, i.e., the barycentric coordinates, private.

  2. 2.

    We provide a novel theoretical analysis of the objective function of Dataset Dictionary Learning (DaDiL)Â [5], showing that, for small perturbations, it behaves as a quadratic form on the atomsâ€™ feature vectors.

  3. 3.

    We provide extensive empirical results on five visual DA benchmarks, showing that (i) our strategy has superior performance on all datasets, (ii) FedDaDiL is lightweight compared to communicating the parameters of deep neural nets. Over the tested benchmarks, communicating dictionaries with the server corresponds to approximately 34.6%Â±23.3%plus-or-minuspercent34.6percent23.334.6\%\pm 23.3\% of the total amount of bits used to encode ResNet weights, and (iii) FedDaDiL is more robust w.r.t. client parallelism than previous methods.

Especially, this paper extends the previous workÂ [20] in two important ways. First, we average atoms in a similar way to FedAVG, which proved to be effective (c.f., sectionÂ 4). Second, we provide a new theoretical analysis on the loss function being minimizing throughout dictionary learning.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ 2 presents related work on dictionary learning and decentralized MSDA. SectionÂ 3 presents our novel approach for decentralized MSDA, constituted of FedAVG (sectionÂ 3.2) and FedDaDiL (sectionÂ 3.3). SectionÂ 4 presents our experiments on various visual DA benchmarks. Finally, sectionÂ 5 concludes this paper.

2 Related Work

Dictionary Learning seeks to decompose a set of vectors {ğ±1,â‹¯,ğ±N}subscriptğ±1â‹¯subscriptğ±ğ‘\{\mathbf{x}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{N}\}, ğ±â„“âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ±â„“superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{\ell}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, as a linear combination of atoms {ğ©1,â‹¯â€‹ğ©K}subscriptğ©1â‹¯subscriptğ©ğ¾\{\mathbf{p}_{1},\cdots\mathbf{p}_{K}\}, weighted by representation vectors {Î±1,â‹¯,Î±N}subscriptğ›¼1â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘\{\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{N}\}. When ğ±â„“subscriptğ±â„“\mathbf{x}_{\ell} are histograms (i.e., âˆ‘jxâ„“,j=1subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥â„“ğ‘—1\sum_{j}x_{\ell,j}=1 and xâ„“,jâ‰¥0subscriptğ‘¥â„“ğ‘—0x_{\ell,j}\geq 0), OT defines meaningful loss functionsÂ [21], as well as novel ways of aggregating atomsÂ [22]. Additionally, decentralized strategies for learning dictionaries have been proposed byÂ [23] and [24], respectively. In this work we use a different interpretation of dictionary learning, in which the atoms are empirical probability distributionsÂ [5]. To the best of our knowledge, ours is the first decentralized algorithm for dictionaries of empirical distributions.

Decentralized Domain Adaptation. Dataset heterogeneity is a major challenge in supervised learning, as commonly used tools, such as Empirical Risk Minimization (ERM)Â [25] work under the assumption of i.i.d. data. This issue also emerges in decentralized settings, such as federated learningÂ [9], in which client data follow different probability distributionsÂ [26]. In this paper we consider decentralized MSDA, where on top of clients with different probability distributions, we have an unique client, called target, who do not possess labeled data. Different ideas in MSDA have been adapted to the decentralized setting. Federated Adversarial Domain Adaptation (FADA)Â [6] uses the adversarial learning framework ofÂ [27] with an additional feature disentanglementÂ [28] module. Knowledge Distillation and Decentralized Domain Adaptation (KD3A)Â [7] uses knowledge distillationÂ [29, 30] and pseudo-labeling for the adaptation. Finally, Co2-Learning with Multi-Domain Attention (Co-MDA)Â [8] studies black box DA, a type of source-free DAÂ [31], where one has access only to outputs of source client models.

InÂ [5], authors presented a novel dictionary learning framework over empirical distributions (cf. eq.Â 1). The DaDiL framework introduces virtual distributions, ğ’«={P^k}k=1Kğ’«superscriptsubscriptsubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\mathcal{P}=\{\hat{P}_{k}\}_{k=1}^{K}, called atoms. In practice, DaDiL relies on features extracted by a neural net, so that barycenters are calculated in a semantically rich latent space. Furthermore,Â [5] minimizes eq.Â 7 via mini-batches.

Our method parts from the following observation: while the atoms ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} are shared by all domains, the barycentric coordinates Î±â„“subscriptğ›¼â„“\alpha_{\ell} are specific to each domain, and thus do are not aggregated nor communicated throughout federated dictionary learning. Next, we describe the two ingredients for our FedDaDiL strategy.

3.2 Federated Learning an Encoder Network

Our FedDaDiL framework works over extracted features of a deep neural net. In a decentralized setting, clients cannot centralize their data for fine-tuning an existing architecture. To keep our overall pipeline end-to-end decentralized, we choose to fine-tune an encoder using the FedAVG algorithm ofÂ [9]. Contrary to existing worksÂ [6, 7], we do not align the probability distributions of clientsâ€™ features. This choice is important, because the dictionary learning step must have a rich variety of probability distributions for modeling distributional shift.

In this context, let Ï•:ğ’³â†’ğ’µ:italic-Ï•â†’ğ’³ğ’µ\phi:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Z} be the encoder network, which takes as inputs images ğ±i(Qâ„“)superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„â„“\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(Q_{\ell})} and outputs a vector ğ³i(Qâ„“)=Ï•â€‹(ğ±i(Qâ„“))âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„â„“italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„â„“superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{z}_{i}^{(Q_{\ell})}=\phi(\mathbf{x}_{i}^{(Q_{\ell})})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Likewise, let h:ğ’µâ†’ğ’´:â„â†’ğ’µğ’´h:\mathcal{Z}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} be a classifier. Complexity. Since algorithmÂ 2 runs over mini-batches, the overall computational complexity on clients is cubic over the size of mini-batches nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b}Â [5, Â§Â§\S 4]. Furthermore, at each round, clientsâ€™ communicate

3.4 Domain Adaptation

The dictionary learned at the end of AlgorithmÂ 1 models the distributional shift occurring between sources and target domains. Unlike previous works on decentralized MSDA, we do not align the sources with the target. We rather embrace distributional shift by modeling it. To learn a classifier at the target domain we have two strategies, Reconstruction (R) or Ensembling (E)Â [5], which we now describe. Both methods stem from the fact that each P^ksubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘˜\hat{P}_{k} has a labeled support, i.e., (ğ™(Pk),ğ˜(Pk))superscriptğ™subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜superscriptğ˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜(\mathbf{Z}^{(P_{k})},\mathbf{Y}^{(P_{k})}). The following methods can thus be applied locally by the target client for learning a classifier that works on data following its probability distribution.

Reconstructing the Target Domain. Through FedDaDiL, we can express Q^N=â„¬â€‹(Î±N;ğ’«)subscript^ğ‘„ğ‘â„¬subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ’«\hat{Q}_{N}=\mathcal{B}(\alpha_{N};\mathcal{P}). Let (ğ™(BN),ğ˜(BN))superscriptğ™subscriptğµğ‘superscriptğ˜subscriptğµğ‘(\mathbf{Z}^{(B_{N})},\mathbf{Y}^{(B_{N})}) denote the support of B^N=â„¬â€‹(Î±N;ğ’«)subscript^ğµğ‘â„¬subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ’«\hat{B}_{N}=\mathcal{B}(\alpha_{N};\mathcal{P}). These can be expressed in terms of the support of each P^ksubscript^ğ‘ƒğ‘˜\hat{P}_{k}, as,

4 Experiments

We provide a comparison of decentralized MSDA methods on 5 visual adaptation benchmarks, namely: ImageCLEFÂ [38], Caltech-Office 10Â [39], Office 31Â [2], Office-HomeÂ [40] and AdaptiopeÂ [41]. We consider 3 methods from the decentralized MSDA state-of-the-art, namely: FADAÂ [6], KD3AÂ [7] and Co-MDAÂ [8]. These methods were chosen due to their relevance, and availability of source code. Furthermore we consider adaptations of DA methods, such as fğ‘“f-DANNÂ [27, 6] and fâˆ’limit-fromğ‘“f-WDGRLÂ [42]. Further details on the benchmarks, and on the hyper-parameter settings of decentralized MSDA methods are provided in the supplementary materials.

We compare FedDaDiL to other decentralized MSDA strategies over 5 visual DA benchmarks. We present an overview of our results in tableÂ 1. We use standard evaluation protocols in MSDA, namely, we perform adaptation with a ResNetÂ [37] backbone. The size of the backbone is selected to agree with previous researchÂ [6, 7, 8]. We run our experiments on a computer with a Ubuntu 22.04 OS, a 12th Gen Intel(R) CoreTM i9-12900H CPU with 64 GB of RAM, and with a NVIDIA RTX A100 GPU with 4GB of VRAM.

In the following, we divide our experiments in six parts. First, we explore the optimization process of FedDaDiL. Second, we show empirically compare our method with prior art. Third we explore FedDaDiLâ€™s performance with respect client parallelism. Fourth we explore the communication cost of our method. Fifth we analyze hyper-parameter sensitivity. Sixth we visualize the alignment between the target domain and its barycentric reconstruction.

Decentralized Dataset Dictionary Learning. Our empirical analysis is threefold: (i) how averaging different atom versions impacts our algorithm, (ii) visualizing the loss-landscape of fâ€‹(ğ’«,ğ’œ)ğ‘“ğ’«ğ’œf(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{A}) in a 2-D subspace and (iii) plotting FedDaDiLâ€™s objective as a function of communication round. We illustrate our findings on the Caltech-Office 10 and Office 31 benchmarks.

First, given two versions ğ’«â„“â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ’«â„“â‹†\mathcal{P}_{\ell}^{\star}, â„“=0,1â„“01\ell=0,1, we define ğ’«t=(1âˆ’t)â€‹ğ’«0â‹†+tâ€‹ğ’«1â‹†subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡1ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’«0â‹†ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’«1â‹†\mathcal{P}_{t}=(1-t)\mathcal{P}_{0}^{\star}+t\mathcal{P}_{1}^{\star}, tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]. Then, we proceed to evaluate fâ€‹(ğ’«t,ğ’œ)ğ‘“subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ’œf(\mathcal{P}_{t},\mathcal{A}) as a function of tğ‘¡t, which is shown in FigureÂ 2(a). Similarly to FedAVGÂ [9], averaging different atom versions decreases the overall loss, which empirically validates our decentralized strategy.

Second, we explore Theorem 3.1. empirically. Let (ğ’«â‹†,ğ’œâ‹†)superscriptğ’«â‹†superscriptğ’œâ‹†(\mathcal{P}^{\star},\mathcal{A}^{\star}) be a dictionary. We define (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u,v) within [âˆ’1.5,+1.5]2superscript1.51.52[-1.5,+1.5]^{2}, and (ğ’«u,ğ’«v)subscriptğ’«ğ‘¢subscriptğ’«ğ‘£(\mathcal{P}_{u},\mathcal{P}_{v}) such that, for Ïµâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,ğˆd)similar-toitalic-Ïµğ’©0subscriptğˆğ‘‘\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\mathbf{I}_{d}), ğ³i(Pk,u):=Ïµassignsuperscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘¢italic-Ïµ\mathbf{z}_{i}^{(P_{k,u})}:=\epsilon and ğ²i(Pk,u):=ğ²i(Pkâ‹†)assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ²ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜â‹†\mathbf{y}_{i}^{(P_{k,u})}:=\mathbf{y}_{i}^{(P_{k}^{\star})} (resp. vğ‘£v). Our analysis consists on visualizing,

fâ€‹(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£\displaystyle f(u,v) =fâ€‹(ğ’«â‹†+uâ€‹ğ’«u+vâ€‹ğ’«v,ğ’œ),absentğ‘“superscriptğ’«â‹†ğ‘¢subscriptğ’«ğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ’«ğ‘£ğ’œ\displaystyle=f(\mathcal{P}^{\star}+u\mathcal{P}_{u}+v\mathcal{P}_{v},\mathcal{A}),

i.e., randomly perturbing the features of the dictionary ğ’«â‹†superscriptğ’«â‹†\mathcal{P}^{\star}, as in TheoremÂ 3.1. As shown in figureÂ 2, the loss has approximately quadratic level sets on the variables (u,v)ğ‘¢ğ‘£(u,v).

Finally, we analyze how the number of local iterations executed by the clients, Eğ¸E, impacts our federated DiL strategy. At one hand, for an increasing Eğ¸E, one parallelizes the DiL problem, as more iterations are done within clients before averaging the multiple atom versions. At the other hand, if the clients perform many local steps, they risk to overfit the atoms to their own data. Overall, for a wide range of values for Eğ¸E, we verify that DiLâ€™s optimization converges towards a local minima, as shown in figureÂ 2(c). This illustrate an advantage w.r.t. other decentralized MSDA methods, such as KD3AÂ [7], who fix E=1ğ¸1E=1 in their experiments. We provide further analysis w.r.t. decentralized MSDA performance in the next section.

Decentralized Visual Domain Adaptation. In the following we refer to tableÂ 2(e), where we summarize our comparisons. First, FedAVG is a strong baseline when there is a limited amount of data. Indeed, on small benchmarks such as ImageCLEF and Office31, it performs better or equally than existing decentralized MSDA algorithms. This is not true on larger benchmarks, such as Adaptatiope.

Second, non-i.i.d. federated learning methods, such as FedProxÂ [43] are approximately equivalent to FedAVG. While decentralized MSDA is also concerned with learning under non-i.i.d. data, the fact that these methods do not leverage target domain data hinders their performance

Third, our methods, FedDaDiL-E and R are able to outperform FedAVG and other decentralized MSDA benchmarks without aligning domains. Indeed, FedDaDiL works in a fundamentally different way than existing decentralized MSDA algorithms, as it embraces distributional shift. The adaptation is done by reconstructing information on the target domain (FedDaDiL-R, cf. eq.Â 14), or by weighting predictions of atom distributions (FedDaDiL-E, cf. eq.Â 15).

Performance under Client Parallelism. We analyze the performance of FedDaDiL as we increase the degree of client parallelism, which is a function of the number of local iterations Eğ¸E. As we verified in the last section, for an increasing Eğ¸E FedDaDiL converges faster w.r.t. the rounds of communication rğ‘Ÿr. In tableÂ 3, we explore the performance of FedDaDiL-R and E in comparison with KD3AÂ [7] and Co-MDAÂ [8] w.r.t. Eğ¸E. Note that, in these previous works, the authors fixed E=1ğ¸1E=1 in their experiments. They further verified a degradation in performance for an increasing Eğ¸E.

As we verify empirically in tableÂ 3, there is indeed a degradation in KD3A and Co-MDA with an increasing Eğ¸E. Nonetheless, FedDaDiL-R and E keep approximately the same level of performance. As a result, on top of outperforming current SOTA, our method is more resilient to parallelism.

Communication Cost. We compare the communication cost in bits at each round, between FedDaDiL and conventional decentralized MSDA methods, such as FADAÂ [6] and KD3AÂ [7]. To do so, we calculate the total number of parameters in FedDaDiL, which, as we discussed in sectionÂ 3.3, corresponds to |ğ’«|=KÃ—nÃ—(d+nc)ğ’«ğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘|\mathcal{P}|=K\times n\times(d+n_{c}). Further details on the choice of K,nğ¾ğ‘›K,n and nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b} are given in our supplementary materials. We then calculate the number of bits used to communicate these parameters, using 32-bit floating point precision, and divide it by the number of bits used to encode the backbone network, using the same precision. Our results are summarized in figureÂ 3(a).

With respect figureÂ 3(a), while we cannot avoid communicating the whole networks during step 1 (FedAVG), the DaDiL step communicates much less parameters than the network used to encode its inputs. As a result, taking into account tableÂ 3 and figureÂ 3(a), the DaDiL step has better communication efficiency than previous decentralized MSDA methods.

Parameter Sensitivity. Here, we evaluate the sensitivity of FedDaDiL adaptation performance with respect its hyper-parameters, namely, number of samples nğ‘›n, batch size nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b} and number of atoms Kğ¾K. On total, this generates 363636 possible models, whose performance is shown in figureÂ 3(b). Note that, over the chosen range of hyper-parameters, FedDaDiL has a performance of 77.6Â±0.22plus-or-minus77.60.2277.6\pm 0.22, well above the second-best method (KD3AÂ [7], with 76.9%percent76.976.9\% of domain adaptation performance). This shows that, overall, our proposed algorithm is robust with respect the choice of its hyper-parameters. We provide the complete list of hyper-parameters (over all benchmarks) in the supplementary materials. Furthermore, nğ‘›n and Kğ¾K control the complexity of our dictionary. From figureÂ 3(b), we see that a small number of atoms (e.g., Kâ‰¤3ğ¾3K\leq 3) and samples (e.g., n=1950ğ‘›1950n=1950) yields the best results. In these cases, we are strictly reducing the total number of samples, as 1950Ã—3=5850<15500195035850155001950\times 3=5850<15500 in the Office-Home benchmark.

Feature Visualization. We compare the alignment of distributions with our method and those of KD3A and FADA. In our case, we align the target with â„¬â€‹(Î±N;ğ’«)â„¬subscriptğ›¼ğ‘ğ’«\mathcal{B}(\alpha_{N};\mathcal{P}), whereas other methods align the target with the source domains. We visualize these alignments by embedding the samples in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} through t-SNEÂ [44] (c.f., figureÂ 4). While the alignment towards domains Webcam and dSLR works well, aligning the sources with Amazon is more challenging. In this case FedDaDiL manages to reconstruct it with dictionary learning, which explains its superior performance.

Dataset Distillation. We explore the use of DaDiL for dataset distillationÂ [45], i.e., creating a reduced summary for a given dataset. We do so in an Federated DA (FDA) setting, i.e., without labeled sampels in the target domain being summarized. As such, we analyze B^Tsubscript^ğµğ‘‡\hat{B}_{T} as a function of nB=ncÃ—SPCsubscriptğ‘›ğµsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘SPCn_{B}=n_{c}\times\text{SPC}, for SPCâˆˆ{1,10,20}SPC11020\text{SPC}\in\{1,10,20\}.

In figureÂ 5 (a-c), we analyze points in B^Tsubscript^ğµğ‘‡\hat{B}_{T} in comparison with Q^Tsubscript^ğ‘„ğ‘‡\hat{Q}_{T} through t-SNE. We use the synthetic domain in Adaptiope as target domain. As SPC grows, one captures progressively better the target distribution. Furthermore, the confidence of reconstructed labels, measured through the entropy, increases with SPC, as shown in figuresÂ 5 (d-f) and (g-i). These results agree with previous research involving distillation and Wasserstein barycentersÂ [46].

Finally, we analyze the performance of summaries created through DaDiL in figuresÂ 5 (j-l), in comparison with random sampling the sources and target domain. DaDiL summariesâ€™ performance increases rapidly with Samples per Class (SPC), but becomes constant as we increase the amount of data. As such, DaDiL achieves novel performance with a summary with 1.67%percent1.671.67\% of the total amount of samples.

5 Conclusion

We propose a novel federated algorithm for learning dictionaries of empirical distributions for federated domain adaptation. The main idea of our approach is keeping server atoms public, whereas clientsâ€™ barycentric coordinates are private. Our strategy is based on two steps. First, one leans a neural net encoder through standard FedAVGÂ [9]. Second, we rethink the DaDiL strategyÂ [5] in a federated setting. Our end-to-end decentralized DA strategy improves adaptation performance on 5 visual DA benchmarks (tableÂ 2(e)). On top of that, we show that our strategy handles client parallelism better than previous works (figureÂ 2(c) and tableÂ 3), while being relatively lightweight in comparison with communication deep neural netsâ€™ parameters (figureÂ 3(a)). We further show that our method is robust with respect its hyper-parameters (figureÂ 3(b)), and that the alignment between the target domain and its reconstruction is better than with source domains (figureÂ 4).

Appendix C Experiments

In this section, we give details about the hyper-parameters used in our paper, for the sake of reproducibility. These concern third-party code open-sourced on Github or OpenReview from the methods used in our paper.

C.1 Reproducing the State-of-the-art

In our experiments, we execute the code of 3 state-of-the-art methods, namely, FADA111Code available at https://openreview.net/forum?id=HJezF3VYPBÂ [6], KD3A222Code available at https://github.com/FengHZ/KD3A/tree/masterÂ [7] and Co-MDA333Code available at https://github.com/Xinhui-99/CoMDAÂ [8]. We selected these methods due to their relevance, and the availability of open source code. These resources allowed us to make fair comparisons to the existing methods. Here, we make some remarks about how we run third party code,

  1. 1.

    FADAÂ [6] runs the k-Means clustering algorithm within its fit procedure, where the number of clusters equals the number of classes ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c}. Due to the internal workings of the authors code, the input for k-Means must have at least ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c} elements. For datasets with small number of classes, such as Caltech-Office, ImageClef and Office 31, we were able to run the authors code. Howerver, the batch size required for running their code on Office-Home (656565 classes) and Adaptiope (123123123 classes) was beyond the hardware capabilities used in this work.

  2. 2.

    All of our experiments, including those with KD3A, Co-MDA and FADA, use torchvision ResNets as backbones with pre-trained weights on ImageNetÂ [47]. We use the IMAGENET1K_V2 weights.

With our design choices, we were able to improve the average adaptation performance of KD3A on Office-Home to 76.2%percent76.276.2\%, in comparison with what was previously reported byÂ [8].

C.2 Hyper-Parameter Settings

FedAVG has hyper-parameter associated with its training process, i.e., batch size, number of epochs, learning rate and weight decay. Globally, we use an Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) optimizer with a momentum term of 0.90.90.9. On all datasets we use a mini-batches of 323232 samples. The training is conducted for 121212 epochs, where an epoch corresponds to a complete run through the entire dataset of all clients. The learning rate is 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2} and we use a weight decay term of 5Ã—10âˆ’4absentsuperscript104\times 10^{-4}. Like previous works on decentralized MSDAÂ [7, 8], we average clients weights at the end of each epoch.

KD3A and Co-MDA. On their respective repositories, the authors of KD3A and Co-MDA present the hyper-parameters of their methods. For Adaptiope, we re-use the hyper-parameters used for DomainNet.

FedaDiL. For our method, we performed grid-search on the batch size nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b}, number of atoms Kğ¾K and number of samples nğ‘›n. For the number of atoms, we search over Kâˆˆ{2,â‹¯,6}ğ¾2â‹¯6K\in\{2,\cdots,6\}. We further parametrize nbsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{b} and nğ‘›n by the number of classes ncsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘n_{c} (c.f., Table 1 in our main paper). We display the best parameters in table 2 below, alongside the cost of communication for this set of parameters. Note that, as we explore in our experiments, the performance of our method is robust with respect the choice of hyper-parameters.
